keyTakeAways: Thieves used power tools, including a disc cutter and basket lift, to break into the Louvre’s Galerie d’Apollon in just four minutes.
Eight priceless jewels were stolen from the French crown jewels collection, with a ninth item — the crown of Empress Eugenie — recovered after being dropped.
The theft occurred during museum opening hours, demonstrating a high level of planning and professionalism.
The Louvre, home to the Mona Lisa, closed temporarily due to the incident and forensic investigations were launched.
French authorities confirmed the use of motorbikes for escape and cited CCTV review and forensic analysis as ongoing actions.
The event is part of a pattern of recent museum attacks in France, including thefts from the Natural History Museum and Cognacq-Jay museum.
The Louvre has a history of high-profile thefts, such as the 1911 Mona Lisa theft and the 1983 armory heist, highlighting long-standing security vulnerabilities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a brazen four-minute heist at the Louvre Museum in Paris, thieves used a basket lift and disc cutter to break into the Galerie d’Apollon, stealing eight priceless items from the French crown jewels. A ninth item, Empress Eugenie’s crown, was recovered after being dropped. The operation, described by officials as being carried out by professionals, occurred during museum opening hours and involved the use of power tools and motorbikes. The incident led to a temporary closure of the Louvre, with forensic teams and CCTV review underway. This event follows a pattern of recent museum thefts in France, including attacks at the Natural History Museum and Cognacq-Jay Museum, underscoring systemic security concerns within France’s cultural institutions.
title: ‘Priceless’ jewels stolen from France’s Louvre Museum in four-minute heist
